title: Warm Brussels Sprouts Salad with Bacon and Apple

description: This warm Brussels sprouts salad is a delightful medley of crispy bacon, sweet apples, and toasted pecans, all tossed in a bright maple-orange dressing. It's the perfect hearty side dish for fall and winter meals that will impress your family and friends.
ingredients: 2 teaspoons fresh lemon juice or orange juice
instructions: Toast the pecans in a large skillet over medium heat for 3–5 minutes until lightly browned and fragrant. Transfer to a plate and set aside.
Add the bacon to the skillet and cook until crisp. Transfer to a paper-towel-lined plate, leaving 1 tablespoon of bacon grease in the skillet.

Add the sliced shallot to the skillet and sauté for about 2 minutes until softened. Add the garlic, shredded Brussels sprouts, salt, and pepper. Cook for 8–10 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the sprouts are browned. Remove from heat and stir in the lemon or orange juice.
Transfer the Brussels sprouts to a serving dish. Chop the bacon into bite-size pieces and add it to the Brussels sprouts along with the dried cranberries, apple, and toasted pecans. Toss to combine.

In a small bowl, whisk together the olive oil, fresh orange juice, maple syrup, Dijon mustard, salt, and pepper. Pour the dressing over the salad and toss to combine. If desired, top with parmesan cheese before serving. Serve warm.
tips: For the best results, ensure the Brussels sprouts are fresh and not overcooked. Toasting the pecans enhances their flavor, and using a mix of sweet and tart apples adds depth to the salad.

structured_content.content: This warm Brussels sprouts salad is a delightful combination of flavors and textures that will make your taste buds dance. The crispy bacon pairs perfectly with the sweet apples and crunchy pecans, all brought together by a zesty maple-orange dressing. It's not just a salad; it's a celebration of fall ingredients!

structured_content.content: I first made this salad for a family gathering, and it quickly became a favorite. The combination of warm Brussels sprouts with the crispy bacon and sweet apples was a hit, and now it's a staple at our holiday dinners.

• Main ingredient: Fresh Brussels sprouts are key for this salad; they should be shredded for even cooking.
  • Key seasonings/flavoring agents: The maple syrup and Dijon mustard in the dressing add a sweet and tangy flavor that complements the salad beautifully.
  • Supporting ingredients: Bacon adds a savory crunch, while apples and cranberries provide sweetness and color.
  • Equipment needed: A large skillet, mixing bowls, and a whisk are essential for preparing this dish.

Preparation:
Start by toasting the pecans and cooking the bacon. Prepare the Brussels sprouts by shredding them finely.
Cooking/Baking Process:
Cook the shallots and garlic in the bacon grease, then add the Brussels sprouts and seasonings. Stir until cooked through.
Finishing Touches:
Combine all ingredients in a serving dish, toss with the dressing, and garnish with parmesan if desired.

note.label: You Must Know
note.content:
• Cook the Brussels sprouts just until tender to maintain a slight crunch.
  • Avoid overcooking the bacon to prevent it from becoming chewy.
  • Look for a golden-brown color on the Brussels sprouts as an indicator of doneness.
  • Store leftovers in an airtight container for up to 5 days.

structured_content.content: This salad is not just a dish; it's a memory of sharing good times with loved ones. The warmth of the salad and the joy it brings to the table make it a cherished recipe in our family.
Consider adding a sprinkle of feta cheese for a tangy twist or some chopped herbs like parsley or thyme for freshness. A dash of cayenne pepper can also add a nice kick!
This salad pairs wonderfully with roasted meats, grilled chicken, or as a hearty side for a holiday feast. A glass of crisp white wine complements the flavors beautifully.
For a gluten-free version, ensure your Dijon mustard is gluten-free. You can also substitute the bacon with roasted chickpeas or sweet potatoes for a vegetarian option.
